column1: The earliest signs of human settlement in the area date to 800 BC. Early settlers were likely attracted by easily mined iron ore and a ford in the Meurthe River. Its name is first attested as Nanciaco
column2: possibly from a Gaulish personal name. A small fortified town named Nanciacum (Nancy) was built by Gérard
column3: Duke of Lorraine around 1050.

column1: Nancy was burned in 1218 at the end of the War of Succession of Champagne
column2: and conquered by Emperor Frederick II. It was rebuilt in stone over the next few centuries as it grew in importance as the capital of the Duchy of Lorraine. Duke Charles the Bold of Burgundy
column3: was defeated and killed in the Battle of Nancy in 1477; René II
column4: Duke of Lorraine became the ruler.

column1: Following the failure of both Emperor Joseph I and Emperor Charles VI to produce a son and heir
column2: the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 left the throne to the latter's next child. This turned out to be a daughter
column3: Maria Theresa of Austria. In 1736
column4: Emperor Charles arranged her marriage to Duke François of Lorraine
column5: who reluctantly agreed to exchange his ancestral lands for the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.

column1: The exiled Polish king Stanisław Leszczyński
column2: father-in-law of the French king Louis XV
column3: was then given the vacant duchy of Lorraine. Under his nominal rule
column4: Nancy experienced growth and a flowering of Baroque culture and architecture. Stanislaus oversaw the construction of Place Stanislaus
column5: a major square and development connecting the old medieval with a newer part of the city. Upon Stanisław's death in February 1766
column6: Lorraine and Barrois became a regular government of the Kingdom of France. A parlement for Lorraine and Barrois was established in Nancy in 1776.As unrest surfaced within the French armed forces during the French Revolution
column9: took place in Nancy in the latter part of summer 1790. A few units loyal to the government laid siege to the town and shot or imprisoned the mutineers.

column2: Nancy remained French when Prussia annexed Alsace-Lorraine. The flow of refugees reaching Nancy doubled its population in three decades. Artistic
column3: academic
column4: financial and industrial excellence flourished
column5: establishing what is still the Capital of Lorraine's trademark to this day.Nancy and other areas of France were occupied by German forces from 1940
column6: renamed Nanzig. During the Lorraine Campaign of World War II
column7: Nancy was liberated from Nazi Germany by the U.S. Third Army in September 1944

column1: Nancy is situated on the left bank of the river Meurthe
column2: about 10 km upstream from its confluence with the Moselle. The Marne–Rhine Canal runs through the city
column3: parallel to the Meurthe. Nancy is surrounded by hills that are about 150 m higher than the city center
column4: which is situated at 200 m above mean sea level. The area of Nancy proper is relatively small: 15 km2. Its built-up area is continuous with those of its adjacent suburbs. The neighboring communes of Nancy are: Jarville-la-Malgrange

column1: The oldest part of Nancy is the quarter Vieille Ville – Léopold
column2: which contains the 14th century Porte de la Craffe
column3: the Palace of the Dukes of Lorraine
column4: the Porte Désilles and the 19th century St-Epvre basilica. Adjacent to its south is the quarter Charles III – Centre Ville
column5: which is the 16th–18th century "new town". This quarter contains the famous Place Stanislas
column7: the Opéra national de Lorraine and the main railway station.

column1: The population of the city proper experienced a small decrease in population from 2009 to 2014
column3: 619) as the second largest city in the Lorraine. However
column4: the urban area of Metz experienced population decline from 1990 to 2010 while the urban area of Nancy grew over the same period
column5: becoming the largest urban area in Lorraine and second largest in the "Grand Est" region of northeastern France. Within the Nancy metropolitan area in recent years
column6: the city population declined slightly (2009–2014) at the roughly same time as a small increase in the population of its urban area (2006–2012).

column1: Nancy has an oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb)
column2: although a bit more extreme than most of the larger French cities. By the standards of France it is a "continental" climate with a certain degree of maritimy (unrelated to the Köppen classification
column3: since generally the whole country has a predominant mechanism favored by the West winds).The temperatures have a distinct variation of the temperate zone
column4: both during the day and between seasons but without being very different. Winters are cold and dry in freezing climates. Summers are not always sunny
column5: but warm enough. Mists are frequent in autumn and the winds are light and not too violent. Precipitation tends to be less abundant than in the west of the country. Sunshine hours are almost identical to Paris and the snowy days are the same as Strasbourg (most similar weather conditions). Although the lowest recorded temperature is officially −26.8 °C
column6: some sources consider temperatures from −30 °C on 10 December 1879 before continuous data.

column1: The old city center's heritage dates from the Middle Ages to the 18th century. The cathedral of Nancy
column2: the Triumphal Arch and the "Place de la Carriere" are a fine examples of 18th-century architecture. The Palace of the Dukes of Lorraine is the former princely residence of the rulers. The palace houses the Musée Lorrain.

column1: A historic church is the Church of Notre-Dame-de-Bonsecours
column3: final resting place of the last duke Stanislas. Other notable churches are the Church of Saint-François-des-Cordeliers and the Basilica of Saint-Epvre (fr:Basilique Saint-Epvre de Nancy)
column4: which have historical ties to the ducal House of Lorraine.

column1: The Place Stanislas named after king of Poland and duke of Lorraine Stanislaus I

column2: a group of artists and architects founded by the glassmaster and furniture maker Émile Gallé
column3: worked in the art nouveau style at the end of the 19th century and the early 20th century. It was principally their work which made Nancy a center of art and architecture that rivaled Paris and helped give the city the nickname "Capitale de l'Est". The city still possesses many Art Nouveau buildings (mostly banks or private homes). Furniture
column4: glassware
column5: and other pieces of the decorative arts are conserved at the Musée de l'École de Nancy

column7: a Nancy businessman and supporter of the Art Nouveau there. The Musée des Beaux-Arts has further collections of the art nouveau movement.

is a so-called 'tramway on tires'
column4: which is actually a guided busway based on Bombardier Transportation's Guided Light Transit (GLT) technology and using articulated trolleybuses. In addition to diesel buses
column5: Nancy has been served by trolleybuses since 1982
column6: but in 2000 the three-route trolleybus system was reconfigured into a single
column7: longer route and with a surface guidance system added (GLT
column8: or TVR in French). The guidance systems covers about two-thirds of the approximately 10-km route
column9: and the trolleybuses are separated from other traffic over that portion of the route
column10: speeding travel times. During its first two years
column11: the new system suffered many incidents and malfunctions of the guidance system
column12: but now works without significant problems.

column1: The coat of arms of Nancy displays a thistle
column2: originally considered to be a symbol of Virgin Mary
column3: and adopted as a personal symbol by René of Anjou and later by his descendant René II
column4: Duke of Lorraine. Contrary to the Scottish thistle
column5: the one of Lorraine is always shown with its roots. During the wars against Burgundy
column6: the thistle became an emblem for the people of Lorraine as a whole. It officially became the attribute of the city of Nancy in 1575 when Charles III
column7: Duke of Lorraine granted the city with its own coat of arms.At first
column8: the coat of arms of Nancy had a chief of Lorraine
column9: which meant that the upper part showed the ducal arms
column10: namely three alerions on a red bend. Later
column11: the chief of Lorraine was replaced by a more complex one which gathers the former possessions of the Dukes of Lorraine. The upper row comprises from left to right the arms of the Kingdom of Hungary
column13: the Kingdom of Jerusalem and the Kingdom of Aragon
column14: while the lower row comprises the Duchy of Anjou
column16: the Duchy of Jülich and the County of Bar. The inescutcheon is the coat of arms of Lorraine itself.The coat of arms displays the motto
column17: which appeared in the end of the 16th century. It was initially "Nul ne s'y frotte" ("no one attacks it")
column18: but it was changed to Latin "Non inultus premor" in 1616. The motto has a similar meaning to the Scottish one
column20: usually translated as "No one attacks me with impunity"
column21: which also makes reference to the thistle. The coat of arms further displays the Legion of Honour
column22: awarded to the city after the First World War
